web_research.query: What are winning approaches for text classification with metadata features on Kaggle?
web_research.finding: Winning Kaggle solutions for text‑classification tasks that also contain rich metadata usually treat the non‑text fields as a **second modality** and fuse them with a strong language model.  A common recipe is to (1) fine‑tune a pretrained transformer (BERT, RoBERTa, etc.) on the raw text, (2) encode categorical or numerical metadata either as additional tokens that are prepended/appended to the input sequence or as separate embeddings that are concatenated to the final CLS vector, and (3) train a lightweight tabular model (e.g., LightGBM, CatBoost) on the same metadata and blend its predictions with the transformer output.  This “text‑plus‑metadata” strategy is illustrated by the Messagenet approach, which builds dedicated blocks for each metadata type (sender, timestamp, etc.) and jointly trains them with a BERT backbone, yielding higher accuracy than text‑only models ([arxiv](https://export.arxiv.org/pdf/2301.01808v1.pdf)). web_research.query: What are winning solutions for Reddit text classification competitions on Kaggle?
web_research.finding:
Winning solutions for the Reddit‑text‑classification challenges on Kaggle have typically combined strong preprocessing with an ensemble of classical machine‑learning models. In the most‑cited Kaggle entry for a Reddit‑comments dataset, the authors first cleaned the posts, removed stop‑words and applied TF‑IDF weighting, then used a χ² test to select the most informative features.  They trained several classifiers (including a custom implementation of Bernoulli Naive Bayes) and combined them in an ensemble, which outperformed any single model and achieved ≈ 61 % accuracy on a held‑out validation split and ≈ 58.6 % on the official Kaggle test set ([nikhilpodila](https://github.com/nikhilpodila/Reddit-Classification)).

web_research.query: What are the best techniques for handling class imbalance in text classification competitions?
web_research.finding: Class imbalance is a pervasive problem in text‑classification contests because many real‑world label distributions follow a long‑tail pattern (e.g., sentiment, medical codes, patent categories).  The most effective ways to mitigate it combine **data‑level** and **algorithm‑level** strategies.  At the data level, oversampling the minority classes (random oversampling, SMOTE and its variants, or more sophisticated synthetic text generation) and undersampling the majority classes are still the workhorses; the imbalanced‑learn library provides a comprehensive guide to these samplers and shows how they can be applied to multi‑class text data ([imbalanced‑learn](https://imbalanced-learn.org/stable/user_guide.html)).
